Context: The eight months I've been dating my boyfriend, I have lied about a lot of things. I slept with a couple guys to get back at my boyfriend for breaking up with me. Now anything I say to him he won't believe, even if I'm being honest. I don't know what else to do at this point. He constantly criticizes me.
True_Response: Start a conversation with him about your sincere interest to earn back his trust.Ask him what he expects from you so that he will trust you again.If you are consciously willing and do try to earn back his trust, and have periodic conversations with him on whether he feels more at ease with trusting you, then after a few months of this, both of you should feel more secure in the relationship.
Generated_Response: Hi Nashville, I'm not sure if you're asking what to do with the relationship, or if you're asking how to stop lying and start trusting. Let's look at both. First, I want to say that it's okay to lie to someone if it's to protect yourself. I think you're lying to protect yourself from his criticism, and that's okay. It's also okay to not trust someone who is criticizing you. I think you're protecting yourself from being hurt. But here's the thing: If you want a relationship with someone who you can trust, who you can trust you, and who will treat you with respect, you have to start by doing that with yourself. You have to trust yourself enough to be honest, and you have to respect yourself enough to treat yourself with kindness and honesty. You can't expect others to do that for you if you're not doing it for yourself. The good news is that you already know how to be kind and honest with yourself. You're already doing it, in a way. You know that lying isn't good for you. You know that criticizing yourself isn't good for you. You know that you don't like it when he treats you that way. You know that you want better for yourself. That's a good start. The next step is to start doing that for yourself. Start with little things. If you're going to lie, start by lying to yourself less. Can you tell yourself the truth about the little things? Can you be honest with yourself about your feelings? Can you be kind to yourself when you make a mistake? Can you say "I'm sorry" to yourself? Can you be patient with yourself? Can you do small things that you know will make you feel better? And then, when you're ready, can you start doing that with him? Can you tell him the truth about the little things? Can you tell him how you feel? Can you ask him to be kind to you? Can you ask him to listen to you? Can you ask him to respect you? It's a process. Start with the little things. You can do this.

Context: My fiancé doesn't think I trust him because I was cheated on before. However, he hides his phone and has been texting his ex-girlfriend, who he has two kids with. What should I do?
True_Response: Oh Chino, I only have half the picture here so I will be cautious. There's a chicken and an egg, and I don't know which came first. One thing I see clearly is that your fiance will always have to have communications with his ex, because they have children. Can you accept that? When suspicion and insecurity come along, your job is to look at the big picture and the real picture. Is there any real evidence that he is cheating? Remember that texting his ex is not evidence alone if the communications are about the kids. Has he earned your trust? If so, then it's not fair to punish him for the betrayals of others. He's not your ex. Reassure your heart that you are his priority if the larger evidence supports that. At the same time, you can let him know what your triggers are. For example, hiding his phone doesn't send you a good message, right? See, this is the chicken and the egg...is he hiding the phone because you've been overreacting when he gets a text?  So let him know you won't blow up about him getting a text if he doesn't conceal or password his phone. Transparency helps build trust. You have sensitivities, and it helps you a lot if he's aware of them and willing to try not to do things that trigger fear. Let him know when you get scared, and hopefully he'll give you the openness and security you need in order to trust him and act as if you trust him.  :)
Generated_Response: Hi! It sounds like you're feeling a lot of anxiety and insecurity right now, and I'm glad you're reaching out. I would also suggest having a conversation about your relationship and how you would like to move forward. If you feel that your fiancé is not willing to make any changes, I would encourage you to seek out some individual counseling to work through your feelings and concerns. You are not alone, and you deserve to feel secure in your relationship. I hope that helps!

Context: We've been dating for two months now. I have a heavy past that gets him angry. Does he have a right to penalize me for things I did before I met him?
True_Response: Not in my book. You're only two months in? At this early stage, this is a bit of a warning sign. If he can't accept or feel comfortable with who you are and decisions you've made, there's already a level of discomfort here that shouldn't be ignored. No, he doesn't have the right to penalize you or punish you ...not just for past things...not for anything. What he does get to do it tell you how it affects him. Sure...if he feels uncomfortable or needs reassurance...listen to those things. But If he doesn't dig who you are, maybe he can walk the other way.
Generated_Response: Hi, I'm glad you asked this question.  I think many people have this question and don't know how to address it.  It's hard to know how to respond when we feel like we are being blamed for something that we did in the past, especially if it's something that we're already trying to make amends for.  I think it's important to remember that we can't change the past, and it's important to learn from it, but we can't change it.  When we are being blamed for something that we did in the past, it's helpful to look at the intention behind the words.  Is your boyfriend trying to shame you, or is he trying to communicate that he's hurt and needs support?  I think it's important to communicate with your partner about how you feel and what you need.  For example, you could say "I'm trying to make amends for what I did in the past, and I'm working hard to do better.  When you blame me for things that I did in the past, it hurts me.  I know you're trying to tell me how you feel, but it's coming across as blaming, and I'm not sure how to respond.  Can we talk about this?"  I hope this helps.  Best of luck to you.

Context: My roommate has had a drinking problem for a while. She goes out, gets trashed, and then expects everyone to take care of her. You hate me. Tell me you love me," and I feel like I have to pity her because she has also been suicidal before.
True_Response: It does sound like your roommate may have a drinking problem, and the short answer is that you can't do anything about it, only she can. We can't change what other people say, think, or do. We can only change our reactions. It does sound like your roommate may be having a hard time. You can suggest that she enter counseling or therapy. You can reassure her that you like her (if that's true), but you don't have to pity her.
Generated_Response: Hi Winters, It sounds like your roommate is a bit of a drama queen, but she's also in a lot of pain. Her behaviour is not normal, and it's also not healthy for you. I'd encourage you to have a talk with her about your feelings and boundaries. You don't have to pity her, and you don't have to validate her. It's not your job to fix her or make her feel better. It's her job to take care of herself. It's okay to say "I'm sorry you're feeling sad, but I can't fix that. You have to take care of yourself." I'd also encourage you to find a therapist who can help you set some boundaries, and help you develop some self-care strategies. It's not your job to take care of someone else, and you can't do it anyway. Take care of you.

Context: After first meeting the client, what is the process that a counselor facilitates?
True_Response: Hi.  This is an excellent question !   I think that the answer probably varies depending upon the particular therapist .  In my work with people , once we have met and I have gotten an idea of the person'a concerns and the issues they want help with , I spend the next few sessions gathering as much history and as much information about the client's current concerns in order to formulate some ideas about what may be causing distress .  I would then share my thoughts with the client to see if they feel I am understanding them and on the right track.  We would then discuss the best plan to address the client's concerns .  Usually I will suggest strategies that I think may be helpful and ask the client for feedback about whether or not they think my suggestions feel helpful .   I always encourage clients to be really honest with me about this.  I tell them that I would hate for them to agree to try things that they know they won't try just to avoid "hurting my feelings" or "offending me."  I want to be helpful and while I have the expertise as far as typically helpful  strategies, I really like to work collaboratively and have clients tell me what they do and don't like / agree with or not agree with when I share my thoughts about a treatment plan .  We the   work together to come up with a plan that will be helpful , but also realistic and then revise it and try new things if necessary as we go along.   If things aren't improving , I am very happy and willing to try something new ! I hope this is helpful for you !
Generated_Response: The first meeting with a therapist is usually to get a feel for the person and their concerns.  It is also a time to see if you and the therapist are a good match.  In the next meeting, the therapist will usually ask a lot of questions to learn more about your life and what you are going through.  From there, the therapist will help you set some goals for therapy and decide on a treatment plan.  This is not a one size fits all plan and will change as you move through therapy.  It is also important to remember that therapy does not always go in a straight line.  Sometimes you may need to go back to an earlier step or even start over.  The most important thing is to communicate with your therapist about what is going on and what you are experiencing.  This way they can help you move through the process as smoothly as possible.

Context: I feel really uncomfortable when I have people's attention.  It makes me not want to talk in public or answer questions in class. Can I get over this social anxiety?

Context: When I see something I don’t like, I go off like a ticking time bomb. I go from “0 to 100” really quickly.

One of the strategies that almost always helps is deep breathing. When faced with a stressful situation, you can give yourself a time out by removing yourself from the stress and spend 5 minutes taking deep breaths (breathe in slowly counting to 4 and breathe out even slower counting to 6), while focusing and thinking only about your breathing. After doing so, think of the various ways you can respond to the situation and choose the one most appropriate. Good luck!

Context: He's been losing feelings and he doesn't know why. I love him very very much. He sometimes thinks I'm obsessed when I'm not at all. I give him his space and I make sure he's okay but sometimes I think if me and him saw each other more it would be better? I truly want me and him to get better, it's kind of hard not to stress about it, because the love of my life is losing feelings which is a sad feeling. He's a great guy! I just don't know why he's been losing feelings towards me. He's starting to put less effort in talking to me. At this point I'll do anything to just make us better as a couple. I tried talking to him but he doesn't like talking about it much. Advice on what to do?
True_Response: I'm willing to bet that this isn't what you are hoping to hear, but I'd suggest giving him space. Ooph, that's a tough one, right?! I know. But here's the thing, when you keep trying to process and talk it out with him you keep pushing him away. He needs to feel like a solid and whole person (as you do too) to be able to be fully in your relationship. It's the work of being in relationship to learn this. I get that this is tough stuff. I wonder, outside of being with him, how do you soothe and calm yourself? That's the stuff for you to tune into and focus on right now.
Generated_Response: Hi there, I'm glad that you're reaching out for help.  I'm also sorry that you're going through this.  It's hard to be in a relationship where your partner is losing feelings for you.  I'm not sure if you're in a long distance relationship or not.  If you are, it's understandable that you may not see each other as much as you'd like.  But if you're not, I would definitely think about how much you're seeing each other and how that may be impacting the relationship.  You mentioned that he's not really interested in talking about it.  That's a red flag for me.  I would be very concerned about that.  It's important to talk about things in a relationship and if you're partner doesn't want to talk about it, it's a big concern.  I would suggest going to see a local therapist and see if you can get some help with this.  I would also encourage you to do some self reflection about what you're looking for in a relationship and what you want.  If you're not getting that from your current relationship, you may need to consider if this is the relationship for you.  I wish you the best of luck.  Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

Context: I believe my partner has a masturbation and porn problem. He masturbates daily, even when I am lying in bed sleeping beside him. We have sex once a week. He is rough and worries about his needs. He never touches me, and treats me like a porn star, wanting to finish on my face or chest.
True_Response: It sounds like your in quite a rough place, my recommendation just based on what you type might warrant a visit to a psychotherapist to resolve what may be going on, I am not entirely sure but it sounds like he might have a bit of a sex addiction problem. One thing you need to ask yourself is "Am I happy?", "Do I feel loved?", these are deep questions, but the answers to those questions will give you a direction to travel in.
Generated_Response: This is a great question. It sounds like you have a lot of questions and concerns about your partner and your sexual relationship. It's hard to know what's going on without knowing more about both of you. It's also important to note that there is a difference between a sex and porn addiction. It's possible that he has a sex addiction and not a porn addiction, or it could be the other way around. It's also possible that he has both. If you are both willing, I would encourage you to see a sex therapist. It's possible that you both have different sex drives and that's why you have different sex needs. It's also possible that there is an underlying issue that is getting in the way of your sexual connection. A sex therapist can help you to explore your concerns and answer your questions.

Context: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
True_Response: Please feel free to cry during therapy if you suddenly feel painful emotions arising when you describe some of your unsatisfying and unfulfilling relationships and situations.Crying when realizing the emotional hurt and unfairness between you and someone, clears you for new ways of handling interactions.As a therapist, I always have a box of tissues on the table next to the couch where people who utilize my therapy, sit.I hope you will soon discover that once your tears unlock your awareness of harmful relationships in your life, you will quickly see the freedom to establish new and happier patterns of relating.Have a good therapy!
Generated_Response: Crying is a natural response to feeling sad, but it is also a way of releasing stress and tension.  Many people cry during therapy sessions, and it is not something to be embarrassed about.  If you are worried about crying, it may be helpful to bring tissues with you.  If you are worried about what others in the waiting room may think, you could also try to schedule your appointment for a time when there are likely to be fewer people in the waiting room (such as early in the day).  Remember that a good therapist will accept you and your feelings without judgment.

Context: How do I decide if I should end my relationship with my boyfriend?
True_Response: This is a tough decision to make for anyone that has ever been involved in a relationship.  My advice is for you to consider what is making you unhappy in this relationship.  Sometimes we think we are ready to move on but don't know the reason why and then we regret it.  The worst thing you want after the fact is to have regret.  Take time to do some soul searching and imagine your life without this person before you make any decisions.  This will also help you understand what it is you are looking for in a romantic relationship. Best of luck in your love life. Mirella~Image and Likeness Counseling
Generated_Response: I'm not sure whether you're referring to a short term relationship or a long term relationship.  I'll give you my perspective on long term relationships, but the same ideas can be applied to shorter relationships as well.  First of all, I think it's important to look at the reasons for wanting to end the relationship.  Are you unhappy?  Is there a specific reason for your unhappiness?  Are you being treated poorly?  Is there a lack of respect?  Is there a lack of communication?  Are you unhappy with the way you are being treated?  Is there a lack of intimacy?  These are just a few examples, but I hope you get the idea.  If there is a specific reason for your unhappiness, you can try to work on it with your partner.  Communication is key.  If you can communicate your needs and wants, and if you can listen to your partner's needs and wants, then you can try to work on finding a solution.  If you're both willing to work on it and you both have the same goal of making the relationship work, then it's worth trying to make it work.  If one of you is not willing to work on it, then it may be time to move on.  However, if you're not sure of the reason for your unhappiness, or if you can't seem to work out the issues, then it may be time to move on.  I think it's important to make sure that you are both on the same page and both want to work on the relationship.  If you are both willing to work on it and you are both committed to the relationship, then it's worth trying to make it work.  If you're both not willing to work on it, or if you're not both committed to the relationship, then it may be time to move on.  I hope this helps.  Take care.

Context:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
True_Response: The short answer is: absolutely not! The longer answer is that it might take some time to process all of the issues, and it may feel quite "muddy" in the issues for a lot longer than is tolerable (which is why counseling may have been postponed to begin with for you.) It's important to be realistic when entering counseling of any sort, and that the therapist be realistic with you about what you might be able to expect working with that person (I use the words "might be able to expect" because therapy experiences can vary.) But that not having counseling about trauma that you have experienced much earlier in your life can play a significant role in the process and how long that process could take to unpack all that may have been buried over time.It might also be helpful in counseling to work with the therapist on figuring out where to begin, but to also manage the feelings of being overwhelmed that may make it hard to continue to show up and do the work required, week in and week out. It isn't easy work trying to process past pain that you experienced, and so consistent practice of self-care, including leaning on support systems outside of therapy, is key.
Generated_Response: No, you do not have too many issues for counseling.  In fact, many people who seek counseling have multiple issues they would like to work on.  A good therapist will help you prioritize your concerns and work on the ones that are most important to you.  It's also important to remember that many of the issues you mention are related.  For example, sexual abuse can lead to depression, anxiety, and sleep issues.  By working on one issue, you may see improvements in some of the others as well.  I would encourage you to seek out counseling to help you with the many issues you are facing.

Context: I have PTSD. The side effects are really bad and have impacts on sex, anger and my relationships. I even lost my job month ago.    How can I get my life back?
True_Response: Slowly is the rate at which you'll get back your life.Being traumatized means not feeling safe in almost all areas of life.Be patient with yourself as you try to regain trust that people will not harm you and will be sources of satisfaction in your life.It is possible that the trauma in your life requires such great attention on your part to your own inner emotional safety that you are better off with a less intensive job than the one you recently lost.Try to prioritize restoring your emotional and psychological health.  With this as the top area of your attention then you may have an easier time to accept a lesser degree of involvement in your work and relationships.When you feel angry, try to examine if underlying the anger are feelings of stress, fear, insecurity regarding your position in relationship to the person toward whom you feel angry.   Anger is often the surface reaction to more destabilizing emotions like fear and insecurity.Gradually by nurturing and comforting yourself, living at a pace which is uniquely comfortable to what and how much you can handle, you'll regain your trust in both yourself and relating to others.

Context: I read that you should ignore them and they have to come to a conclusion that they were wrong on their own terms. Is that correct?
True_Response: It is not correct because someone who is narcissistic believes they are always right.If you ignore the person, then their thinking is that there is something wrong with you.Ignoring the person to the degree this is possible in the situation or relationship, will spare you to be misunderstood further.
Generated_Response: The best way to handle any situation is to be able to communicate effectively.  When you are in a disagreement with someone, it is important to understand that they have their own opinion and you have yours.  You can disagree with someone's opinion and still respect them as a person.  If you can listen to their point of view and share yours in a respectful manner, there is a greater chance of reaching a conclusion that is agreeable to both of you.  If you are not able to come to a conclusion together, then it is important to agree to disagree.  This means that you accept that you have different opinions and that is okay.  You do not have to change your opinion and they do not have to change theirs.  It is also important to remember that you can agree to disagree in a respectful manner.  You do not have to yell, scream, or be disrespectful to someone just because you disagree with them.  If you are able to disagree respectfully, you may find that you can still have a good relationship with them even though you disagree on certain things.  This is a very important skill to learn because you will meet many people in your life that will have different opinions than you.  It is important to be able to communicate with them effectively and respectfully.

Context:
What am I doing wrong? My wife and I are fighting all the time. What can I do? We don't agree on anything and she usually jumps to conclusions, which are usually wrong on how I feel. She is very family-oriented while all of my family left me on my butt, abused, ignored and messed up with me mentally. I'm not a family-oriented person. I only have two people in my life - my best friend and my wife.  

My mother forced my father out of my life so I do not know who he really is. We've gotten in contact but he just makes comments on how much I look like her when in fact I look more like him.  This makes me mad because I don't want to look like my mother. I hate her. All that she did was bring me down and make me homeless, which she was successful at.  I need guidance in my life.  I don't want to lose my wife but we need to have a space because we usually hit each other and it's not healthy. I'm dying to make our relationship healthy. I've never wanted anything more than this. Please help me. I need your advice.
True_Response: Hello. It sounds to me like you are carrying an enormous amount of emotional weight, and maybe even an equally enormous amount of guilt and feelings of failure about your marriage. I cannot imagine how challenging this is for you right now. Marriages take lots of work, and often the only examples we tend to have are of those we saw when we were young - good, bad, or indifferent. There are no easy answers to your questions, and I won't presume that my response to you will be the linch-pin that heals all your pain. But I can maybe give some thoughts and reflections. First and foremost, cut yourself some slack. No one is perfect. We fail more often than we succeed, but in the end we learn, and that learning helps us grow. Yes, you're right, the abusive aspects of your marriage are not good, and need to stop. You probably are doing more harm than good in that regard, and this will quickly destroy anything you have in your marriage that is even remotely in your favor. Seeing a therapist for yourself, and then seeing a therapist as a couple is a good approach. You have issues that you need to resolve, that, while they impact your marriage because they are part of the history of your life, they are separate from your marriage in many respects.Joining a marriage support group can also be helpful. You can find these through local counseling resources. Sometimes your local crisis numbers can provide services in your area that can be helpful. If you belong to a religious or spiritual community, then you might see if there is any type of counseling offered for free or at a reduced rate. Sometimes pastoral support is focused on the spiritual side of any issues addressed, so if you feel this is important it might be a viable option for you.Lastly, parents are imperfect. Yep...its true. They had no more of a guaranteed parenting success manual than you do at having chances for a perfect marriage. We limp along and do our best. Having said that, we can still take the best from our past and apply to our future, no matter how small or insignificant it might be for us. The bad stuff serves as lessons of what to avoid, and we are each responsible and accountable for our actions in this life. Both with ourselves, and toward other people. So this becomes a guiding principle in our actions. It may be that you discover that the marriage you are in is not a good fit.  I am sure that remains to be seen, but either way you both must be involved in saving it. If only one of you cares, then 100% of the energy to salvage the marriage rests on the shoulders of one person. That's not fair. So be sure you have a clear understanding from your wife about what she wants, and work to create an amicable solution. All of this said, seek out supportive friends, and actively work to do your part to make the changes you want to see in your life. One way or the other, you will benefit from it.Be well.
Generated_Response: I'm so sorry to hear of your suffering. It sounds like you have a lot of pain that you are carrying around. It sounds like you are also in a lot of pain in your relationship. It sounds like you are not able to have the relationship that you would like. It is very important that you seek out counseling in your area to work through your issues. You have a lot of pain that you are carrying around. You may be in a lot of pain in your relationship, but you are also carrying around a lot of pain from your past. It is important that you work through these issues. You are also not able to work through your relationship issues on your own. It sounds like you need some help. You may be able to get a sense of whether you need counseling or not by reading the following article. http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/ http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/

Context: I'm obsessing about a terrible breakup. Everything is a constant reminder. How do I move on?
True_Response: The best way to move on is to give yourself sufficient time and space away from your ex so you can heal.  That means no checking out your ex on social media platforms and no contact.  In order to move on and diminish the obsessions, help yourself recognize and accept that the relationship is over, and make sure to get sufficient support in processing all your feelings.  Once that takes place, it can be useful to explore and process with a professional the meaning of the relationship and to understand your part in what transpired.Sometimes people obsess because they have difficulties accepting what's already taken place and want things to be different.  The key to moving forward is to be loving toward yourself, to give yourself permission to grieve the loss, and to start cultivating new and healthy habits/patterns.  Reengage in your present life, ask yourself what you want your life to look like, and start creating goals and taking small steps to create the amazing life you want for yourself.
Generated_Response: The best way to move on from a breakup is to accept the fact that it happened.  I know that may sound simple, but it can be very difficult to accept.  One way to help you accept that it's over is to actually say out loud that you accept that it's over.  Also, try to make a new beginning with yourself.  Maybe get a new haircut, or buy a new outfit, or do something that makes you feel good and new.  I hope this helps.  Best of luck to you.

Context: How does a person start the counseling process?
True_Response: The first thing to do is to reflect on what you want to seek counseling. Search online and then set up a phone consultation. A person can find out a lot about a counselor and the services that they offer over the phone. After a consultation then set up an intake questions. The overall goal is to make sure that you are comfortable with the counselor and the services they can offer.
Generated_Response: Hi there!  Thank you for your question.  Beginning the counseling process can seem daunting, but it is actually very easy.  The first step is to decide what you are looking for in a counselor.  Are you looking for someone who specializes in a particular area (for example, depression, anxiety, trauma, etc.)?  Do you have a specific location in mind?  Do you have a preference for the gender of your counselor?  Once you have decided what you are looking for, you can begin your search.  There are many websites that allow you to search for counselors based on your criteria.  My favorite is called Psychology Today (https://www.psychologytoday.com).  Once you find a counselor that you would like to work with, the next step is to call and schedule an appointment.  Many counselors offer a free phone consultation, which can be a great way to ask questions and determine if the counselor is a good fit for you.  Once you have scheduled an appointment, the counselor will likely ask you to fill out some paperwork before your first session.  Then, you are all set!  It really is that easy!  I hope this was helpful.  Best of luck to you!  :)

Context: I was in a relationship with a woman for four years. We both made mistakes, but I do love her.    She has moved in with another lady. I think she is just cheating on me to make me miss her. How can I find out for sure?
True_Response: Has your former partner made any efforts to be in contact with you in order to restart your relationship?From what you describe, your former partner is in a new relationship.It is possible that since you love her and would like to be together again, that you are misinterpreting your former partner's actions.If you'd like to have more certainty as to wether your former partner is cheating or whether she is happy to be with the new partner, is to contact her and ask her your question.A better road may be to accept your sad feelings that she is with someone else.Since she was meaningful to you, respect the sadness you feel and that the relationship didn't continue as you wished.

Context: My girlfriend just quit drinking and she became really depressed. She told me that she wants to move. What can I do to help her? I want her to stay.
True_Response: You should start by speaking with her about what has her so down. Have their been some significant events in her life that have affected her? Have their been significant events in your relationship that can be affecting  you both? If she just stopped drinking, she may be struggling to finding an alternative and healthier behavior. This is something the two of you can explore together. Also, if need be perhaps she can speak to a therapist to discuss her feelings about quitting alcohol. It sounds like you really care and right now she could use all the support she can get despite her pushing you away.
Generated_Response: I'm sorry your girlfriend is going through this. I can't imagine how difficult it must be for you to see her go through this. I'm not sure how much you know about depression, but it's important to know that it's a very serious illness. It's not just "feeling sad". Depression can be very debilitating and can interfere with daily activities. Depression is caused by a combination of factors, such as genetics, stress, trauma, and even life transitions. It's important to know that depression is very common and can affect anyone. It's also treatable. The best thing you can do for your girlfriend is to support her in getting the help she needs. I would suggest that you talk to her about seeing a therapist. If she's not ready for that, I would suggest that you find a therapist yourself and learn more about depression. There are also some great books about depression that you can read to learn more. One that I would recommend is "Lost Connections" by Johann Hari. If your girlfriend is open to it, I would suggest that you attend therapy with her. It can be very helpful to have the support of loved ones during treatment. If you are not able to attend therapy with her, it's important to remember that you are not responsible for her recovery. You can support her, but you can't force her to get better. You can encourage her to get help, but you can't make her go. It's also important to remember to take care of yourself. Watching a loved one suffer from depression can be very difficult. Make sure you are taking care of your own mental and physical health. This is also something that you can talk to a therapist about.

Context: I'm feeling rejected and frustrated. This is not new. The first month we were together, sex was about every day. Then it slowed down to once a month right away. I love my husband, but I am struggling with this.
True_Response: Feeling rejected and frustrated is a reasonable reaction to your experience with your husband. I want to encourage you that his actions may have little to do with you, and regardless of outcomes, I hope you find the help you need to process through your pain and still have hope for your marriage.   If your husband was to work with me I'd explore with him his understanding of, and experience with, intimacy in relationship with others. Furthermore, like other male clients of mine, I'd challenge your husband to secure an updated full medical exam from his PCP (primary care physician) and/or urologist in order to identify or rule out any organic issues which may be causing his apparent lack of desire for sexual intimacy. If there are no physical issues, per se, I would encourage your husband to process further his family of origin story-line regarding rules, roles, sex, and sexuality along with working through his sexual and trauma histories.
Generated_Response: Hi! I'm glad you're reaching out! I'm so sorry you're struggling with this. I'm not surprised you're feeling rejected and frustrated, because I think anyone would feel that way in this situation. There are many possible reasons for low sexual desire in a partner, and it's hard to say from here what's going on. I would encourage you to have a conversation with your husband about this, and see if you can get some insight into what's going on for him. If you can't, or if you feel like you're not getting the information you need, I would encourage you both to seek out a qualified sex therapist. There is help available!

Context: My daughter didn't see her biological father for the last three years. She doesn’t want to see him because she remember really bad things from him such as domestic violence and child abuse. Context: My parents seem okay with other sexualities, but normally they only talk about being gay. When they do talk about bisexuality, they say things like “they'll do anything” or things that make me very uncomfortable because I am bisexual. I don't know if I am ready to come out to them.

Context: I've been going through a rough time lately. I been into nothing but women. I’ve never thought about men until a week ago. I’m very upset and depressed about this. It's not normal to me. I looked at gay porn more than once to prove that I’m not gay. I get the same results each time, and I feel disgust. This is tough on me. I'm scared that I looked too many times. I keep thinking about it and shake all the time.
True_Response: Hello. Coming to terms with the idea that you might be of a sexuality other than the one in which you were socially raised to be, can be emotionally disturbing, and quite unsettling. It creates anxiety, maybe even panic, and leaves us feeling confused and uncertain about our own sense of identity. It becomes important to first ask yourself how you feel when you are thinking of being intimate with guys, or if you desire them to be intimate with you. It is important to know what impact this has on you, because it can determine your level of follow through and desire in pursuing sexual activity with someone of the same sex. I am not going to pass judgment on you either way - even for having the thoughts. I have worked with the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer (LGBTQ) community in various ways over the years. Many I speak to, say they had to struggle to come to terms with this awareness about how they see themselves sexually. Maybe you are bisexual, and don't have an exclusive attraction to the same sex. You might consider doing some searches online for community support groups in your area, to explore the feelings and issues around this topic. Talking to someone who you trust can be helpful too. Running from your feelings is not a good idea, and others in a support group for sexuality issues, might be able to relate to you and what you're going through right now. This will offer you perspective, as you think on how this plays out in your life.Counselors are typically well trained to provide clinical services to clients who are experiencing feelings and thoughts much like the ones you are having now. I encourage you to consider reaching out for help. You are not crazy or insane for thinking of working with a counselor, nor of having feelings of same sex attraction. If you decide you are indeed gay, then know that you are not alone and never will be alone in that feeling. There is a huge community of support for you. Additionally, we all need help sometimes dealing with all sort of issues. A counselor can work more in depth with you to examine the motivations behind the feelings, and help you come to terms with them more directly. I hope that you come to a place where you feel less alone and more secure with yourself as you examine this area of your life. No matter what, do not fear being yourself. Again...you are not alone, I promise.Warm regards,Shawn Berthel, M.S., LMHC
Generated_Response: Hi! I'm so glad you wrote. You're not alone in feeling confused about your sexuality. This is something that many people struggle with and it's actually a very normal thing. There are many people who are attracted to both men and women. There are also people who are attracted to one gender when they are young and then later in life realize they are attracted to the other gender. I encourage you to take some time to explore your feelings and thoughts about your sexuality. It's important to accept and embrace who you are and to live the life that you want. You can't control who you are attracted to, but you can control how you react to your feelings. Context: I have known her for years. She was dating my brother-in-law when we met. My kids think of her as their aunt. On Halloween 2014, I lost my mom to cancer. Context:
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job.
   People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?
True_Response: Hi, It is really good that you are working so hard to take care of your family. Anxiety can be so challenging, especially when new challenges have come up. It would be good to work through some of these issues you are experiencing, and examine your self care and support processes.
Generated_Response: Hi, It sounds like you're feeling a bit overwhelmed by the new job and the travel that it requires. You're not alone - lots of people feel this way when they take on a new role, especially if it requires them to travel far away from home and family. It's important to remember that anxiety is actually a natural response that we all have, and it's not necessarily a bad thing. In fact, it's actually a great thing when it helps us to be prepared for a new challenge. When we're feeling anxious, our bodies are preparing us for action. So, if we're anxious about a new job, our body is preparing us to take on that new challenge. I think that the key here is to learn how to manage your anxiety so that it doesn't interfere with your ability to do your job. There are a lot of different strategies that you can use to do this. One of the things that you can do is to make sure that you're getting enough sleep and exercise. These are two things that can really help to reduce your anxiety. Another thing that you can do is to practice some relaxation techniques. There are lots of different ones out there, but some that you might want to try are deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and meditation. There are lots of resources out there that can help you to learn these techniques. You can also try to practice some mindfulness. This is basically just being present in the moment and not worrying about the future or dwelling on the past. You can also try to challenge your anxious thoughts. When you notice that you're having an anxious thought, try to reframe it in a more positive way. For example, instead of thinking "I can't do this job", you could think "I can do this job, and I'm going to be okay". You can also try to use positive self-talk. This is basically just talking to yourself in a positive way. For example, you could say "I've got this" or "I can do this". Another thing that you can try is to use some visualization techniques. This is basically just imagining yourself doing well in your new job. You can also try to use some distraction techniques. This is basically just doing something that you enjoy to distract yourself from your anxiety. For example, you could listen to music or read a book. I hope that some of these strategies are helpful for you. I would also encourage you to seek out some professional help if you feel like your anxiety is really interfering with your ability to do your job. A therapist can help you to develop some strategies that are specific to you and your situation.

Context:
I'm in my late teens and live with my dad.  The only time I go out is for my college classes. Sometimes when I see my friends I want to talk with them, but sometimes I won't want to talk to them for days or even weeks. 

Sometimes I feel i'm not worth knowing or i'm never going to do anything right.

Are they right, am I depressed?
True_Response: Hello. Being a teenager in our society today can cause depression quite easily. We look at the world in which we live, and the doubts we have about being able to make a contribution, or to have value and worth with the people around us, and we begin to internalize those messages of self-worth. If that alone were not enough, you are trying to figure out where you want to go in life, and who you are supposed to be in the world. Teens are faced with pressures of being judged by your peers for how you present yourself; following current fashions; possessing the trendy things; and hanging out with the "in crowd." Here's a "secret" that might help with most of those issues: Not much of those problems I've just described will really matter as they might seem to right now, in the real world. If you are feeling depression because you feel you lack some of those things that are seen as important by others (like your peers), I can assure you that being someone who is kind; compassionate; understanding of another person's suffering; and the effort you make to be the best person you can become in the world, will far outweigh anything you experienced in your teen years.When we are young, we judge everything based on what our peers have, what they say, the way they dress, who's popular, who's not popular, and for the most of it, all of that is external. So the question becomes, are you trying to fix the feelings on the inside (the internal stuff), with the trappings of all the stuff on the outside (the internal)? That is to say, do you feel that if you had what your friends have, you would be happy and less depressed? Depression is usually a symptom of something much bigger, it is not typically a problem by itself (just as a person who experiences a high temperature may likely have a cold). So fixing the symptom requires looking at the possible causes. In your post, you mentioned that you live with your dad. Are your parents divorced or separated, or has your mom passed away? Either of these circumstances could certainly cause depression. Finding out when you started feeling depressed, might be able to pinpoint the trigger that caused it, which requires looking at when you last felt really happy. It is also important to keep in mind, that as a teenager, your emotions are often being experienced very randomly, and sometimes without cause. It is part of your emotional development, but as you grow older can learn how to manage those emotions better and practice doing things that help you feel better (without causing harm to yourself).Have you tried talking to your dad about your feelings, or maybe another relative if you feel safer doing so? Do you have a friend who is your best friend...someone who is there for you no matter what? If not, there is a service you can use that is a national number for teens to talk with teen peer counselors. They are teens like yourself, but they have some insights that might be helpful. Its called Teen Line (https://teenlineonline.org/). It helped me when I was in my teens, and has helped lots of other teens as well. You might find a place to get some referrals to other local services in your area. If you want are in Washington state and would like to connect with me directly, you call link to me via my profile page. Or perhaps finding a counselor in your local area might be useful. Most towns and cities have some form of low cost counseling. You might also check with your school for assistance.Don't be afraid of not always knowing how you are supposed to feel. Adults don't always have a handle on it either. Being a teenager carries a lot stress, fear, and uncertainty. But you are not alone, and there is help if you reach out for it. I wish for you the very best, and bright future.
Generated_Response: It sounds like you may be experiencing some symptoms of depression. However, a trained mental health professional would need to assess you to determine if you meet the criteria for a diagnosis of depression. If you are experiencing symptoms that are causing distress and interfering with your ability to function, I would encourage you to seek out counseling.

They are serious and need to be treated by a professional. If you have severe depression and anxiety you should seek out a therapist immediately.

True_Response: I'm glad to hear you have friends and that your friends say they like you.Trust your own sense of who you are which tells you that something feels uneasy within yourself.Is the friend who says you're "just fine", very familiar with who you are?"Friend" is a broad category.She may not know you as fully as you know yourself.Basically, it is possible to be "fine" and have some inner stress.Follow your own thoughts and observations to more fully learn about yourself in ways your friend may not notice or be aware.

Be kind and compassionate to yourself. I hope this helps. I wish you the best of luck.

One in four women will be sexually assaulted or raped in her lifetime. It is very common for people who have been sexually assaulted or raped to experience PTSD. I would encourage you to seek out a counselor who specializes in treating trauma. There are treatments that are very effective for trauma. However, it is important that you have someone who specializes in trauma treatment. If you do not know of a counselor who specializes in trauma, you can contact your local mental health association. They can help you find a counselor. If you are a college student, you can contact your school's counseling center. They should be able to help you. I hope this was helpful. Be well.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPCC, NCC

Context: I've hit my head on walls and floors ever since I was young. I sometimes still do it but I don't exactly know why,    I have anxiety and I had a rough childhood but now I'll start to hit my head and sometimes not realize it but I don't know how to stop or even why I'm doing it.    How can I help myself to change my behavior?
True_Response: The best way to handle anxiety of this level is with a combination of appropriate medication given to you by a medical doctor, and therapy to help you understand the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that are causing the anxiety. This is not something that anyone should just “white knuckle” and try to get through on their own with no help. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is a technique that has been proven helpful for depression and anxiety. This takes a therapist trained in CBT. You will learn to recognize when and why you perform the behavior of hitting your head, help you deal with the underlying cause of this, and replace the behavior with a more positive behavior. You'll learn coping skills.You mention having a rough childhood. Anyone who has experienced trauma like this, especially long-term ongoing trauma from abuse of any kind, definitely does not need "exposure therapy", which is what is recommended for phobias. You need a therapist trained specifically in trauma informed therapy.You are on the right path by recognizing there is an issue and what it is. Good luck with your healing journey!
Generated_Response: This is a great question. There are many different reasons why a person would hit their head, and it's hard to know the exact reason without knowing a lot more about you and your history. However, it's great that you're already aware of the behavior and want to change it. I would suggest talking with a therapist who can help you figure out the function of the behavior (why you're doing it) and then you can come up with some alternative behaviors that serve the same purpose. For example, if you are hitting your head when you are anxious, maybe you could find another way to cope with anxiety that is less harmful, like deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation. If you are hitting your head when you are frustrated, maybe you could find another way to cope with frustration, like taking a break and going to a quiet place. I would also suggest talking with your primary care physician and/or a neurologist to rule out any medical issues that may be contributing to this behavior.

Context: My husband and I had our first threesome recently. Everyone was drinking and he was on her more then me.    He and I talked about it afterwards and it made me feel better, and now I'm craving more of it. But before it gets close to happening I get this empty feeling. Why am I feeling this way?
True_Response: You need to have an honest conversation with each other about WHY you both want a threesome. Evaluate the status of your relationship with each other. Are you having issues? Fighting? Not feeling satisfied with each other? How has your sex life been with each other?  If there are any problems, insecurities, issues, introducing something like this may only make your relationship worse. Open relationships and threesomes rarely work out well. Sure, there are some who successfully live this lifestyle, but it only works when both people are completely secure in their relationship with each other, harbor no jealousies or insecurities, and aren't looking to someone else to satisfy needs that aren't getting met by their spouse. Let me say that again: This is not likely to work out well for you if either of you are insecure, jealous, or looking to have needs met by this other person that you aren't getting from your spouse. That empty feeling you're having - listen to it. Dig deep to find out where it is coming from. What thoughts are going through your head when you feel that way? You'll get the answer.The other thing that helps make something like this work is for both of you to listen and respect each other. If you don't like it that he paid more attention to the other girl, he needs to know that, and he needs to respect that.  If you're going to do it again, he needs to know what you're comfortable with and what you want. Set the limits before you're in the moment, before it's too late to take an action back. Turn it around and ask him what he would be comfortable with if it were a man instead of a woman.It is perfectly natural to be curious and want to experiment. A lot of people get that out of the way before settling down in a monogamous relationship. People who marry young and/or inexperienced may still feel that curiosity about things like that and want to experience them, but don't want to hurt their spouse. The REASON you are both doing this matters a lot. If there are problems in your relationship, this is likely to only make things worse.
Generated_Response: Hi there, I'm so glad you asked this question. I have had a number of clients come to me with similar concerns. It's so important to be able to talk about it. I think it's great that you and your husband are talking about your experiences. This is so important. You said that "it made me feel better" but you still have this empty feeling. I wonder if you can tell me a little bit more about this empty feeling. I wonder what it is that you are craving more of. I would encourage you to explore this with your husband. What is it that you are craving? Is it the threesome itself or is it the feeling that you get during the threesome? I would also encourage you to explore this feeling. What does it feel like? Where do you feel it in your body? Where does it start? Where does it end? Is it a particular colour? What is it telling you? I would also encourage you to explore what is underneath this feeling. What is it that you are afraid of? What is it that you are worried about? What is the worst thing that could happen? What is the best thing that could happen? What is the most realistic thing that could happen? You may find that this feeling is just a feeling and it doesn't mean anything. It may just be a feeling. It may just be your body's way of telling you that it's not ready for another threesome. Or it may be telling you that you need to talk to your husband about something. I hope this was helpful. I would love to hear how you go.

Context: I'm in my mid 20s with a husband and children. I love my family, but I feel like I've lost my identity, and I don't know who I am other than a mom and wife. At times, all I can think is what I gave up and how I feel unhappy and trapped, but I know I'd feel like worse without them. I loathe myself at times. I have an amazing life, so why can't I just enjoy it?
True_Response: It is not easy being a wife and mother. You have shifted roles in your life. You went from having a career to focusing on your family. Transitioning can be hard, especially when we feel we gave something up that we really wanted. I want to acknowledge you for wanting to be the best wife and mother you can. I think it is great that you are self-aware and want to work on this.Feeling "unhappy and trapped" may also mean that you are  believing these negative thoughts are absolutely true. We have lots and lots of thoughts throughout the day. Sometimes we pay a lot of attention to some and some we ignore. Right now these thoughts are getting a lot of your attention and perhaps you are thinking because you are thinking them they are true.  Is it really true that you trapped? You also said that you have an amazing life. It doesn't sound like you are only having negative thoughts. You have some positive ones, too. However, you are giving a lot of weight to the negative thoughts, more weight than the positive ones.I also wonder if you are struggling with the fact that you are even having this thought. One thing that can be helpful is to recognize that you are having a thought, that it is a negative thought, that thinking it does not make it true, and to let it go. This is the basis for mindfulness work that can be really helpful. It is a great place for you to start so you can balance out your thoughts and emotions.Best of luck to you!
Generated_Response: Hi Louisiana, You're not alone in this feeling. I've heard it from so many women, and some men too. I call it the "Mommy Identity Crisis". It's a time when you're feeling a bit lost and you can't remember who you were before you became a parent. It's actually a natural part of the parenting journey. You're not broken. You're not a bad mom. You just need a bit of help getting reacquainted with yourself. The first step is to accept that this is a natural part of the journey. The second step is to give yourself permission to be a "good enough" mom. We can't be perfect. We can't be everything to everyone. We can't be the best mom 100% of the time. We can't be the perfect wife, employee, daughter, friend, and sister. That's a lot of pressure. The third step is to give yourself time to be with yourself. This is where you start to reconnect with your identity. What do you love? What are your interests? What do you want to do? What makes you happy? What do you miss? The fourth step is to schedule in time to do these things. If you don't schedule it in, it won't happen. If you need to, you can ask for help from your partner or family. You can hire someone to help out with the housework or to watch the kids for a few hours. It's okay to ask for help. It's okay to take care of yourself. The fifth step is to find a mom tribe. There are lots of moms out there who are going through the same thing. Find a group that shares your interests and values. This is where you can find support and encouragement. The sixth step is to be patient with yourself. You won't find yourself overnight. It takes time. It takes practice. It takes effort. But it's worth it. You'll be a better mom and wife when you're happy and fulfilled. The seventh step is to remember that it's okay to be a work in progress. You don't have to have it all figured out. You don't have to be perfect. You just have to keep trying. Keep moving forward. Keep growing. Keep learning. Keep loving. Keep being. You're doing great. Keep up the good work.

Context: I am going through a very hard time and I'm so depressed. My parents are getting a divorce and a lot of bad things are happening. I want to lull myself.
True_Response: It sounds like a tough time and it's normal to feel down when your family is going through a divorce or other hardship. There's a difference between feelings like sadness, discouragement, grief, loneliness and depression, though. Sadness is sadness and sometimes we have to go through a grieving or other process, that is a normal reaction to events in our lives. Depression, on the other hand, is more about being stuck. Lulling yourself with self-care sounds like a healthy response and a way to give yourself support. So as to the uncomfortable but healthy part of your feelings, do the best you can to put names to it and share with a trusted other person. You will find comfort. The part of your situation that's depression -- feeling stuck, not able to get out of bad, concentrate, changes in sleeping and eating, loss of enjoyment in living, poor hygiene, feelings of hopelessness, that's different. First step, identify your own symptoms of depression. If you have any thoughts of hurting yourself, tell someone. If you're not sure, you can try 800-lifenet or other support line to get feedback. First aid for depression includes: daily care and feeding, good sleeping and eating, lots of exercise--even when you don't feel like it-- healthy socializing, and focusing on talking to yourself in a positive way. If you aren't able to move yourself out of your depression,  work with a professional to make short-term goals and get some support. You may also talk to your doctor or psychiatrist about trying an anti-depressant to give you a little lift while you go through a rough patch.Best wishes,Karen
Generated_Response: I'm so sorry you're going through this. It's hard when your parents are going through a tough time. I'm glad you're reaching out for help. You don't have to go through this alone. I would suggest that you talk with a local mental health professional. They can help you to learn some coping skills to help you deal with your feelings and get through this difficult time. In addition, you can try some of these coping skills:1. Write in a journal. 2. Draw or paint. 3. Play music. 4. Talk to a friend or family member. 5. Take a walk. 6. Listen to calming music. 7. Breathe deeply. 8. Eat healthy foods. 9. Exercise. 10. Read a book.

Context: I've been with the mother of my child for years.
True_Response: I would think that you hold little self worth and feel that you are not worthy of better.  I would suggest that you get to know yourself.   What do you NEED in a relationship?  What is holding you to this relationship other than your child?  What have gone on in the relationship that makes you think or feel you deserve such disrespect?  Just a few questions to ask yourself..
Generated_Response: I am sorry to hear that you are having some challenges in your relationship.  It is difficult to offer any advice without knowing the details, but I can offer some general thoughts.  The most important thing is to be honest with each other about your feelings.  It is also important to be open to feedback.  If you are open to feedback, then you will be able to listen to what your partner is saying without getting defensive and interrupting.  When you are listening to your partner, try to reflect back what you are hearing to make sure that you understand what they are saying.  If you are able to have an open and honest dialogue with each other, you may be able to come to some resolution.  If you are not able to do this on your own, consider seeing a couples therapist.

Context: I've got so much anger. I don't know how to control myself. My girlfriend screams at me all the time, and sometime I don't know how to deal with life. I'm very depressed and angry. I feel lost.
True_Response: Hi Campbell River, You say you have anger but you don't mention how it shows. Or maybe it doesn't. Are you aggressive with your girlfriend? Since you mention depression, I wonder if you're bottling it all up somewhere instead of letting it show at all. If this is the case, I admire your ability to not lash out at someone who's hurting you. However, if they are totally  unexpressed, anger turn inward and shift into depression. When she yells at you, what do you do? Is this the moment that you feel the most angry? I wouldn't be surprised; anger is a normal response to someone yelling at you. Something about anger...it's often there to cover up our more vulnerable emotions. Under the anger I wonder if you feel worthless, powerless, scared, unloved. Part of the trick to reducing anger is identifying those other emotions and expressing them. You say you don't know how to deal with life, and I think maybe you mean you don't know how to deal with emotions. Lots of people don't! This is confusing for most of us. What am I feeling? Why is it so strong? I'm afraid to express it for fear of hurting someone (or falling apart, or feeling alone...). How do I know what to express and what to be quiet about? These are all great questions to ask yourself, and a qualified therapist can help you sort it all out and support you in your growth. I wish you well!
Generated_Response: It sounds like you have a lot going on right now.  It can be difficult to handle anger and depression on your own, and it sounds like you are struggling to manage these feelings.  I would recommend that you seek out counseling to help you with your depression and anger.  A counselor can help you to find ways to manage your anger and depression, and to find healthy ways to communicate with your girlfriend.  If you need some support to get started, you can talk with your primary care physician or you can call your local mental health association.  You can also find a counselor using this link: https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/therapists

Context: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?
True_Response: Hi!  Great question.  I believe counseling does help people! Of course, I am a therapist, so I would think that! :)  Seriously - I think therapy and counseling allow us to understand ourselves, our motivations and the things that bring us happiness and discontent.  Therapy can create opportunities to try new skills and enhance positive attributes that are already present in someone.  I like to think of therapy as an unbiased "aerial view" of our lives. Someone outside can often help us notice things we might otherwise miss. Hope this helps!
Generated_Response: Counseling is a process of working with a trained professional to explore the areas in your life that are causing you pain, distress, or confusion.  It can be an opportunity to gain new insight into your life, and to learn new skills and tools for coping with challenges.  The best way to determine if counseling is right for you is to give it a try.  You can always stop working with a therapist if you don't feel like it's a good fit.  There are many different styles of therapy, and many therapists offer a free 15 minute phone consultation where you can ask questions about their approach and experience.

Context: My mom made a lot of mistakes a couple years back, and I can't seem to forgive her. I want to say that it's okay, but I can't. I feel like even if I did forgive her, I wouldn't be able to say it to her face.
True_Response: How someone feels when they forgive another, is at peace with themselves and their understanding of what went wrong, who was responsible for what in the situation, and clarity on their own motivation, actions, emotions including pain, regret, resentment, sadness.These steps ideally allow a new door to open in order to develop new paths in the existing relationship or accept that this will not be possible due to either person's way of handling themselves.The long answer would be that you're not yet through with this process.I commend you on being truthful with yourself about yourself.You're on the right track by expecting to feel resolved when you've reached resolution, and not before.Finding patience with the unpredictable amount of time needed to thoroughly examine all the details of the incidents you mention, sometimes is a frustration of its own.Keep up your good work of knowing your own life.It is a worthwhile endeavor!
Generated_Response: Hi, and thank you for your question. Forgiveness can be difficult. We all make mistakes, and sometimes we hurt other people when we do. In fact, we can't avoid it. It's a part of life. The good news is that forgiveness is possible. I don't know the details of what happened between you and your mom, but I imagine that it hurt you deeply. Forgiveness is about letting go of the anger, resentment, and bitterness that we feel towards someone who has hurt us. It's also about being able to move forward in the relationship and rebuild trust. Forgiveness is a process, and it can take time. It's not something that happens overnight. It's also important to note that forgiveness doesn't mean forgetting. It doesn't mean that what happened was okay. It just means that you are ready to move forward and let go of the hurt and anger. I'm not sure if you have read the book, "The Four Agreements," by Don Miguel Ruiz. It's a really great book that talks about forgiveness, among other things. You may want to check it out. There are also many other books on forgiveness. I don't know if you would like to read about it, or if you would like to talk to someone about it. If you want to talk to someone, I would suggest a therapist or a counselor. They can help you to process your feelings and move through the forgiveness process. If you don't want to talk to someone, you can try writing in a journal. There are also some great online forgiveness exercises that you can try. I have not tried them myself, but I have read about them. Here is a link to one that you might like: http://www.greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/five_steps_to_forgivenessI wish you the best of luck as you work through this process. Be patient with yourself. Forgiveness is a process, and it takes time. Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

Context: I’m in my early 20s. My ex’s parents are friends with them and have told them bad things about me. I left my ex due to an abusive situation, and they are making me look like I was the bad one.
True_Response: Maybe you can talk with your partner about this first look at the different elements of a possible conversation in the future. If you are at a place where you are willing or able to disclose the reason that you left your ex, that could be one element of the discussion, but it doesn't have to be.I don't know how long we have been together with your current partner, but perhaps his or her parents would see you for who you are and make their own opinions over time. That may be a discussion to have with them as well.Hopefully your partner will be a good sounding board before these conversations.
Generated_Response: It sounds like you're in a difficult situation. I'm not sure what your goals are here, but I'll offer a few thoughts and suggestions. It's important to remember that you are the only one who can control your behavior and the choices you make. You can't control what other people think or say, but you can control your reactions to it. If you're able to, I'd suggest trying to focus on the people who are supportive of you and spend your time with them. If you're concerned about how this is impacting your relationship with your ex, you may want to consider talking to him about it. If you're not comfortable doing that, or if it doesn't help, you may want to consider talking to a therapist about it. It's also important to remember that you don't have to be friends with your ex's parents. If you're not comfortable being around them, you don't have to be. You can also choose to not talk to them about your relationship. I'm sorry you're going through this. I hope you're able to find a way to handle it that works for you.

Context: How does a person start the counseling process?
True_Response: I'd recommend looking on psychologtoday.com, reading the bio's of potential therapists who you think you would relate best with, then contact them through e-mail or on the phone.
Generated_Response: You can start the counseling process by looking up therapists online, by searching for a therapist on your insurance panel, or by calling a local helpline. When you find a therapist you are interested in, call and schedule an appointment. The first step is usually a phone consultation where you can ask questions and find out if the therapist is a good fit for you. Then you can schedule an in person appointment.

Context: I find that I imagine things sexually, and I hate it because it puts strain on my relationship. I feel helpless and guilty. I want it to go away, and I want to make my woman happy again.
True_Response: It is completely understandable that you would like to find a way to make these intrusive thoughts go away, however, your feeling that you can't control having these thoughts is accurate. It's also understandable that you would feel helpless and guilty, given that you see how these thoughts are effecting your relationship, though I would encourage you to go easy on yourself and remember that you aren't choosing to have these thoughts. I'm sure that if there was a switch to turn them off, you would flip it.There is no magic technique or pill that can guarantee these thoughts will go away, however, therapy may still have a lot to offer. In working with a competent therapist, you may be able to gain insight into where these thoughts are coming from and develop new ways of relating to them so that they do not leave you feeling as helpless and guilty and can be more present with your partner. Though there is no guarantee that the thoughts will go away, this may also be a result of work with a therapist. Either way, you may be able to find a way to deal with the thoughts and show up in your relationship in a way that will be satisfying to you and your partner.
Generated_Response: If you're imagining things sexually with other people, then you're not being faithful to your partner. You may be able to stop thinking about these things, but you're still doing something wrong. Your partner needs to know what's going on and needs to decide if she can forgive you and trust you again. You may want to seek out counseling so that you can address these issues and find a way to be happy in your relationship.

Context: I am a female, and I am afraid of having sex. I am afraid of disappointing my partner by being inexperienced. I think he thinks I'm not a virgin. I am also scared that he will be disappointed with my naked body. I don't want my partner to think differently of me because I am afraid of having sex.
True_Response: As hard as it may be to do this, since all the media and marketing of how an ideal person looks and performs sexually, surrounds us, keep in mind that the images presented in order to sell movies and almost any product, is meant to trigger fantasies.No one is a fantasy, we are all real and unique.  We can be influenced to believe that being a fantasy is better than being who each of us is, genuinely.Your partner may be much more accepting of your body and your level of sexual experience, than you are of yourself!Sex within a relationship means the two people want to have with the other one, not because they have ideal bodies and expertise, but because the person wants to make love to the one whom they love.When you are in a loving relationship, part of this includes talking about sensitivities and insecurities.  Having a conversation gives the chance to know that you are accepted for who you are, not how closely you resemble a made up idea meant to persuade people to buy items.
Generated_Response: Hi! This is a very common fear that many women have. I have worked with many women to help them feel more comfortable with their bodies and to help them feel confident about their sexuality. The first step is to understand that there are many different ways to have sex and you don't have to do anything that you are not comfortable with. Your partner should be able to respect your boundaries and to not pressure you into doing anything that you don't want to do. If you are in a relationship, I would encourage you to have an open conversation with your partner about your fears. You can let him know what you are comfortable with and what you would like to try. You can also let him know what your fears are and that you would like to take things slow and to do what feels good for you. It is important to remember that you should never feel pressured to do anything that you are not comfortable with. If you are not in a relationship, I would encourage you to take things slow and to do what feels good for you. You can explore your body on your own and to learn what feels good. You can also talk to your partner about your fears and to let him know what you are comfortable with. You can also talk to your partner about what you would like to try. I hope this was helpful.

Context: I never feel like myself. I can’t even think straight anymore. I start stuttering and I can’t remember anything. I always get nervous and usually talk myself down but recently end up fighting with, what feels like, someone else. I don’t know why I feel this way, but I hate it.
True_Response: What you are describing sounds like it may be a form of dissociation. Dissociation is our mind's way of disconnecting us from aspects of our experience in an attempt to protect us in overwhelming situations. It also sounds like you are noticing anxiety in certain situations. In working with a competent therapist, you may be able to gain insight into these experiences, learn skills for coping with anxiety and reconnecting with yourself, and alleviate these symptoms over time.
Generated_Response: Hello, and thank you for your question. This is a very serious situation, and you should see a counselor or therapist as soon as possible. It sounds like you are experiencing some serious symptoms of depression, anxiety, or possibly a dissociative disorder. I don't know if you have had a diagnosis from a medical professional, but if you have, it would be a good idea to share this information with a counselor. If you haven't, then seeing a counselor is still a good idea. The counselor can help you determine what is going on and how to address it. If you are not sure where to go, your primary care physician can probably help you find someone.
